channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Part comedy, part masochism: This stand-up show includes a public roast of each comic
item.description: Every Sunday in Austin, there's a comedy show called Banana Phone. Comedians do one minute of stand up material, then the crowd heckles and roasts them until they run out of insults.
item.content:encoded: Every Sunday in Austin, there's a comedy show called Banana Phone. Comedians do one minute of stand up material, then the crowd heckles and roasts them until they run out of insults.
item.dc:creator: Sean Saldana

item.title: On the streets of Beijing, many wish for economic stability this Lunar New Year
item.description: It's the Year of the Fire Horse. In the Chinese zodiac, the fire horse represents action and risk-taking. But on the streets of Beijing, many say they just want stability in this sluggish economy.
item.content:encoded: It's the Year of the Fire Horse. In the Chinese zodiac, the fire horse represents action and risk-taking. But on the streets of Beijing, many say they just want stability in this sluggish economy.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Pak

item.title: Ramadan in Cairo blends the old and the new
item.description: The world's Muslims are preparing for the holy month of Ramadan, a time of fasting and prayer. In Cairo, that means shopping for gifts and buying decorations to get into the spirit of the holy month.
item.content:encoded: The world's Muslims are preparing for the holy month of Ramadan, a time of fasting and prayer. In Cairo, that means shopping for gifts and buying decorations to get into the spirit of the holy month.
item.dc:creator: Aya Batrawy

item.title: Presidential photos and campaign buttons of the past live on as collectibles
item.description: In honor of Presidents' Day, we visit with the folks who collect presidential memorabilia — from pictures of presidential dogs to many many campaign buttons, to deep dives on just one president.
item.content:encoded: In honor of Presidents' Day, we visit with the folks who collect presidential memorabilia — from pictures of presidential dogs to many many campaign buttons, to deep dives on just one president.
item.dc:creator: Buffy Gorrilla

item.title: When the Olympic record is your age! Meet 54-year-old Minnesotan Rich Ruohonen
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with the 54-year-old curler, Rich Ruohonen, the oldest American Winter Olympian to ever compete
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with the 54-year-old curler, Rich Ruohonen, the oldest American Winter Olympian to ever compete
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: Minnesota Democrats blame state Republicans for helping bring on the federal surge
item.description: Republicans in the state legislature invited Nick Shirley to the state where he made misleading videos about immigrant fraud and that helped push Minnesota into the ICE surge.
item.content:encoded: Republicans in the state legislature invited Nick Shirley to the state where he made misleading videos about immigrant fraud and that helped push Minnesota into the ICE surge.
item.dc:creator: Dana Ferguson

item.title: Extremist rhetoric is often found in government messaging. Who's the target?
item.description: In a rare move, the White House took down a racist post last week from one of President Trump's social media accounts. But extremism researchers say it fits a pattern of mainstreaming extremist ideas.
item.content:encoded: In a rare move, the White House took down a racist post last week from one of President Trump's social media accounts. But extremism researchers say it fits a pattern of mainstreaming extremist ideas.
item.dc:creator: Odette Yousef

item.title: How 2016's Black art and culture set the stage for 2026
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers talks to critics Angelica Jade Bastién and Vinson Cunningham about 2016's music, literature, politics, and on-screen representation as the nation celebrates Black History Month.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Juana Summers talks to critics Angelica Jade Bastién and Vinson Cunningham about 2016's music, literature, politics, and on-screen representation as the nation celebrates Black History Month.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Brown

item.title: The 'Zipper Queen' volunteers at repair cafes to restore busted zippers
item.description: Michelle Elise is known in repair cafe circles as the "Zipper Queen." She finds that most broken zippers just need some TLC, not replacing.
item.content:encoded: Michelle Elise is known in repair cafe circles as the "Zipper Queen." She finds that most broken zippers just need some TLC, not replacing.
item.dc:creator: Jeanette Woods

item.title: The U.S. women's hockey team is dominating the Olympics. Now they will play for gold
item.description: The Americans, whose captain Hilary Knight is leading a generation of thrilling young talent, are undefeated through six games at the Olympics — and they're outscoring their opponents 31 to 1.
item.content:encoded:
The Americans, whose captain Hilary Knight is leading a generation of thrilling young talent, are undefeated through six games at the Olympics — and they're outscoring their opponents 31 to 1.

(Image credit: Alexander Nemenov)
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan
